title: Man tied up younger girlfriend then confessed he ‘sliced her up’, court hears
text:
Jason Farrell, 49, wrote a ‘chilling’ letter in which he confessed to killing girlfriend Sammy-Lee Lodwig, 22, Swansea Crown Court heard (Picture: Athena Picture Agency)

A middle-aged man fuelled by jealousy stabbed his younger girlfriend to death after tying her up on a bed, a court has heard.

Jason Farrell, 49, allegedly ‘mercilessly’ attacked Sammy-Lee Lodwig, 22, at his Carlton Terrace flat and then wrote a ‘chilling’ letter in which he confessed that he had ‘sliced her up’.

The defendant used to date the victim’s mother Sarah Lodwig and had expressed a desire to hurt both her, her daughter and the man he suspected she was dating Christopher Maher, Swansea Crown Court heard.

The defendant – who denies murder – wrote in a letter read to the court by prosecutor Michael Jones that he had argued with the victim before repeatedly stabbing her in the face and throat.

Mr Jones read: ‘We went back to my flat and we started arguing.

‘Then the next thing I had her tied up and told her I’d had enough and I was going to kill her.

‘I did by repeatedly stabbing her in the face and throat.’

Mr Jones told the jury: ‘That letter confessed to murder of Sammy-Lee . He’d actually used the word ‘murdered’.

Farrell arrives at Swansea Magistrates Court for an earlier hearing (Picture: Dimitris Legakis/Athena Pictures)

‘We say it’s a chilling document and one you will be able to see and read for yourself.’

Mr Jones said Farrell knocked at a neighbour’s window on April 23, saying: ‘I killed her’.’

A friend of the neighbour then went to the flat with Farrell where he saw Ms Lodwig’s body on a bed.

When the emergency services were called, Farrell fled and paramedics discovered the victim dead and a black-handled kitchen knife covered in blood, with the tip of its 15cm blade missing next to the bed.

She was fully-clothed with cuts across her throat and forehead and there was ‘severe bleeding’ on the bedding.

Farrell – who split with Sarah Lodwig in 2010 after receiving a 13-year sentence for stabbing another man – had started a relationship with the victim after she regularly visited his flat for drugs.

Mr Jones said he also stands accused of a ‘brutal attack’ on Mr Maher days before the alleged murder.

Advertisement

Advertisement

On the morning of Ms Lodwig’s death, Farrell allegedly phoned a friend, calmly telling her, ‘I’ve killed her. I had enough. She wouldn’t shut up. I sliced her up’.

He added that it had been a ‘slow death’, the court heard.

Ms Lodwig started a relationship with Farrell after she regularly visited his flat for drugs, the court heard (Picture: Athena Pictures)

Firearms officers tracked him down to an address near his flat that afternoon, where they convinced him to put down a knife he was holding to his neck before arresting him.

While in custody he said in the presence of officers ‘that girl didn’t deserve to die like that’, the court heard.

Forensic scientist Claire Morse said it appeared the victim had been assaulted on the bed.

Mr Jones said knotted and blood-stained dressing gown belts with traces of Ms Lodwig’s saliva were found nearby, suggesting they may have been in or around her mouth.

Injuries to her neck damaged major arteries and veins, while wounds to her chest were deep enough to enter both her lungs.

Cause of death was given as stab wounds to her neck and chest.

Farrell denies murder, wounding with intent, and unlawful wounding.

The trial continues.

description: Jason Farrell attacked Sammy-Lee Lodwig at his Carlton Terrace flat and then 'wrote a chilling confession letter' Swansea Crown Court heard.
